p: Oxysophoridine belongs to the quinolizidine alkaloid group and is one of the alkaloids extracted from the Chinese medicinal plant Sophora alopecuroides and Siphocampylus verticillatus [ 52, 53]. This alkaloid has various known pharmacological activities, especially in the field of oncology [ 54], and has anti-oxidative stress, strong anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptosis properties [ 53, 55, 56]. Studies investigating the anti-viral properties of this alkaloid have not been very successful but a recent study has reported that SARS-CoV-2 replication is inhibited by oxysophoridine in cell culture (EC 50 0.18 μM and CC 50 > 40 μM) [ 50]. Little-to-nothing is known about the anti-viral mode of action of oxysophoridine, however, and future studies are needed to determine how this alkaloid interferes with coronaviral replication.
